subSense.def: big house or institution
subSense.example:
The police
searched the school grounds for the
weapon

The village fair is held in the
grounds of the hospital

subSense.def: reasons
subSense.example:
Does he have any grounds for com-
plaint?

What grounds have you got
for saying that

subSense.def:
a
floor in a building which is level with
the street

a number of peo-
ple together
subSense.example:
a group of houses in the
valley

Groups of people gathered in
the street

She is leading a group of
businessmen on a tour of Italian facto-
ries

There are reduced prices for
groups of 30 and over

subSense.def:
a way of clas-
sifying things
subSense.example:
These drugs belong to
the same group

subSense.def:
people playing music
together
subSense.example: He plays in a jazz group
She's the lead singer in a pop group

subSense.def:
to live and
develop
subSense.example:
There was grass growing in
the middle of the road

Roses grow
well in our garden

subSense.def:
to make plants
grow
subSense.example:
He grows all his vegetables in
his garden

We are going to grow
some cabbages this year

body.subSense:
3. to become
taller or bigger ć He's grown a lot taller
since I last saw him. ć The profit has
grown to £1m. ć The town's population
is growing very fast. (NOTE: grows -
growing -grew / ru / -grown
/ rəυn/)

subSense.def:
becom-
ing bigger in size or amount

becom-
ing stronger or more extreme
subSense.example:
growing
fear of war

subSense.def: full size
subSense.example:
What
silly behaviour from a grown man

subSense.def: an increase in size
subSense.example:
the rapid growth of the population
since 1980

They measured the tree's
growth over the last fifty years

body.subSense:
so dirty as to
be unpleasant ć A grubby little boy
asked for money. ć He was wearing a
grubby old shirt. (NOTE: grubbier -
grubbiest)

subSense.def:
complain in a
bad-tempered way, especially regularly
and often about unimportant things
subSense.example:
He's always grumbling about the music
from the flat above

subSense.def:
a legal
document in which someone states that
something is going to happen
subSense.example:
The
travel agent could not give a guarantee
that we would be accommodated in the
hotel mentioned in the brochure

subSense.def:
a
promise
subSense.example:
I can't give you any guaran-
tee of success

body.subSense:
to give a firm
promise that something will work, that
something will be done ć I can guaran-
tee that the car will give you no trouble.
ć We can almost guarantee good weath-
er in the Caribbean at this time of year.
(NOTE: guarantees -guaranteeing -
guaranteed)

subSense.def:
a person who pro-
tects, often a soldier
subSense.example:
Security guards
patrol the factory at night

subSense.def:
the man in
charge of a train
subSense.example:
The guard helped my
put my bike into his van

subSense.def:
to watch
someone or somewhere carefully to pre-
vent attacks or escapes
subSense.example:
The prison is
guarded at all times

subSense.def:
a sol-
dier who is not part of a regular national
army

an attempt to give the
right answer or amount
subSense.example:
Go on -make
a guess!

At a guess, I'd say it weighs
about 10 kilos

subSense.def:
to try to give the
right answer or amount
subSense.example:
I would guess
it's about six o'clock

Neither of them
guessed the right answer

He guessed
right

I've bought you a present -shut
your eyes and guess what it is

subSense.def:
a person who is in-
vited to come to your home or to an
event
subSense.example:
We had a very lively party with
dozens of guests

None of the guests
left the party early

subSense.def:
a person staying
in a hotel
subSense.example:
Guests are requested to va-
cate their rooms before midday

subSense.def: advice

a person who shows
you the way
subSense.example:
They used local farmers
as guides through the forest

subSense.def:
a person
who shows tourists round a place
subSense.example:
The
guide showed us round the castle

The
museum guide spoke so fast that we
couldn't understand what she was say-
ing

subSense.example: a guide to Athens

a guide to the but-
terflies of Europe

subSense.def:
to show
someone the way to somewhere
subSense.example:
She
guided us up the steps in the dark

subSense.def:
to
show tourists round a place
subSense.example:
He guided
us round the castle and told us about its
history

subSense.def:
a book
with information about a place

who has com-
mitted a crime
subSense.example:

2. feeling unhappy because you
have done something wrong ć I feel
very guilty about not having written to
you. (NOTE: guiltier -guiltiest)

subSense.def:
a musical instrument
with six strings, played with the fingers
subSense.example: He plays the guitar in a pop group

subSense.def:
an area of sea partly sur-
rounded by land
subSense.example: the Gulf of Mexico

subSense.example:
She spread
gum on the back of the photo and stuck

subSense.def:
the flesh
around the base of your teeth
subSense.example:
Brush-
ing your teeth every day is good for your

body.subSense:
to stick something with
glue ć She gummed the pictures onto a
sheet of paper. (NOTE: gums -gum-
ming -gummed)

subSense.def:
a weapon which
shoots bullets
subSense.example:
The robber pulled out a
gun

She grabbed his gun and shot
him dead

subSense.def:
a small piece of equipment
which you hold in your hand to spray a

subSense.example:
A
spray gun gives an even coating of

subSense.def:
a man armed
with a gun
subSense.example:
The gunman pulled out a
revolver and started shooting

subSense.def:
the tube in which food is
digested as it passes through the body
subSense.example: He complained of a pain in the gut

subSense.def: courage
subSense.example:
She had the guts to tell the
boss he was wrong

subSense.def:
the side of a road
where water can flow
subSense.example:
Pieces of paper
and leaves were blowing about in the
gutter

subSense.def:
an open pipe under the edge of

subSense.example:
It rained so
hard the gutters overflowed

subSense.def: a man

married a guy from Texas

The boss is
a very friendly guy

Hey, you guys,
come and look at this!

subSense.example:

Penny for the
guy

subSense.def:

subSense.example: I go to the gym twice a week to exercise

subSense.def:
physical exercises, especially as an
activity at school

the eighth letter of the al-
phabet, between G and I

something that
someone does regularly
subSense.example:
He has the
habit of biting his fingernails

subSense.def:
tense and past
participle of have
frozen rain
subSense.example:
I thought
the hail was going to break the wind-
screen

subSense.def: to fall as frozen rain
subSense.example:
It
hailed for ten minutes and then the sun
came out

subSense.def:
a mass of long fibres
growing on your head
subSense.example:
She has long

She always brushes her hair
before washing it

You must get your
hair cut
He's had his hair cut short

Use some hair spray to keep your hair
in place

subSense.def:
one of the fibres growing on

subSense.example:

there's a hair in my soup!

left hairs all over the cushion

He's

a person
who cuts and washes your hair

the way in
which your hair has been cut or ar-
ranged

one of two parts which
are the same in size
subSense.example:
She cut the orange
in half

One half of the apple fell on
the carpet
Half of six is three

subSense.def: one of two parts of a match
subSense.example:
Our
team scored a goal in the first half

We
thought we were going to win, and then

30 min-
utes after an hour

a short hol-
iday in the middle of a school term

in the mid-
dle
subSense.example:
Come on, we're more than half-

The post office is about
halfway between the station and our

subSense.def:

The children

subSense.example:
Because the town has no cash, its

subSense.def:
a piece
of minced beef grilled and served in a

a tool with a

subSense.example:

the nail hard with the hammer

subSense.def:
to knock something such as a nail into
something such as a piece of wood with

subSense.example:
It took him a few minutes to

subSense.def: to hit something hard, as with a hammer

She hammered on the door with her
stick

subSense.def:
the part of the body
at the end of each arm, which you use
